commentBody: Language in which "shingle" is...

Again, the link from the main puzzle page is broken.

This seems to happen a lot on Thursday (i.e. Wednesday nights).

Luckily, it's listed in the Wordplay index.

Finished in 12:03, wasted two additional minutes trying to find the Wordplay column. ü•≥

I enjoyed this one. I found the theme interesting, though I basically solved the puzzle without looking to hard at the clues for the highlighted pairs. Instead, I somewhat subliminally noticed that the answer pairs were anagrams of each other, which gave me a decent speed boost!

Wordplay link fixed now. I had no trouble getting to it.
I did have to google what the foreign word was to help solve or I would still have been ASEA.  I‚Äôm ok in French, Spanish, Hawaiian, and Latin. Not CROATIAN, LATVIAN, FLEMISH. After Flemish I did realize that the two sides were anagrams. I had Wowzah before Yowzah. Also had Ghee before SHEA so was hung up in the NW until I figured that out. But despite all that was still under my average.

Axiom #7 of crosswords:

When faced with a theme you haven‚Äôt yet twigged to, it‚Äôs probably anagrams.

My twisted tongue inspired me to look these up:
Raincoat in Latvian: lietusmƒìtelis
Himself in Croatian: sebe
Valiant in Flemish: heldhaftig

Quiz next week.
My fastest Thursday evah! üôåüèª

At first I thought the theme was annoying and esoteric beyond belief.  I worked primarily through crosses, and was doing ok until the SE corner. Then the anagrammatic nature of the themed clues became clear, the revealer made sense and my frustration vanished.  I stand in awe of the linguistic legerdemain that went into this one.

And to top it off, the clue for MADEMAN was top notch.

For reasons I won‚Äôt get into, I was unable to comment on yesterday‚Äôs puzzle, but suffice it to say GUMMO gave me fits.

A bit meh for me I‚Äôm afraid. I always say anagram puzzles need a raisin d‚Äôetre and I‚Äôm not sure this one has one. Sure, you found some languages you can anagram‚Äîgood for you. (And you lose points for admitting to using a computer program instead of the old fashioned scrabble tiles). They will always be symmetrical since they are anagrams, and there will always be a translation so it‚Äôs not like you have to be too clever about it. Points for all the hoops you had to jump through to fit them into the grid (including finding a pair that cross with TONGUETWISTER) and that was an appropriate enough revealer. But it‚Äôs not twisty or challenging enough for a Thursday (the anagrams actually make it easier) so maybe if this were a Tuesday or Wednesday I would have appreciated it more.  I did like the SHEESH and YOWZAH placement and TIL that Swift invented the name VANESSA, so thanks for that. And an extra point for mentioning ‚ÄúSpaceballs‚Äù so I can remind folks that it is getting a long awaited sequel soon‚Äîhope it doesn‚Äôt get swept under the rug like ‚ÄúSpinal Tap 2‚Äù.
Loved this clever puzzle!

As SP said, the anagrams actually made this one easier than a "standard" Thursday (whatever that is). 11 seconds off a PB for me, so while I enjoyed the puzzle, it didn't feel meaty enough for this day of the week.

While anagrams can be a gimme for a thursday, I felt today‚Äôs had enough granola to make me work for the answers.  Using languages that I would not be gimmes for me made this worth it. 

Fun fact that people don‚Äôt know about Saint Paul, MN, we have over 100 languages spoken here. Take that, NYC.
Clever but too easy. Looking forward to struggling through next Thursday‚Äôs challenge.

I got the anagram pretty quickly but I don‚Äôt really understand the tongue twister part?  Maybe it‚Äôs just that kind of day. 

Zichzelf‚Ä¶worth it for the sound of that!
Didn't realise they were anagrams until the very end. An enjoyable, albeit slightly easier (I'm neither complaining, nor boasting) Thursday puzzle.
Clever theme. I liked it.

Very clever and the construction is meticulous. I bet it took a lot of tinkering. 

What language is "Krippe" this? 
GERMAN --> MANGER

(The only other ones I could think of were Nepali / Alpine, but what decent Nepali would ever call anything "alpine"? And English/Shingle, which would be kinda funny to clue; and Polish / [wypolerowanie] polish, which our buddy from Warsaw may or may not like...)

Love that False crosses alarm and the sandwich up there of FARCE ALARM, like when some rube settles in to watch a serious drama and it turns out to be Spaceballs, he might get that rude shock of FARCE ALARM. Which is what happened in reverse when I went on a date to see "Manhattan" thinking it was one of Allen's zany romps. And started laughing uproariously as soon as the film started rolling thinking this was the darndest parody of Bergmanesque romantic agony I had ever seen! I did not end up marrying my date.

Unusually straightforward clueing for a Thursday. I sailed through it almost without pause (rare for me); the nay speed bump was in the SE, where it took a few tries to parse the anagrams.
Overall, enjoyable but not terribly puzzling.

I‚Äôm definitely more of a YOWZAH than a SHEESH today.  

Original theme, with bonus points for finding ALOHA in mahalo.
IMO the anagram angle was the stronger hook for the puzzle than the TONGUETWISTER one, but a fun zippy Thursday nonetheless.

I try not to get hung up on what day what puzzle should run, but I confess to some disappointment in finding this one running as a Thursday puzzle, when I would have been very happy to find it as a Wednesday.   
Didn't need the anagrams for help in solving, but did see them at the end.

I saw an interview with Josh Gad, who showed Spaceballs to his daughter. She then asked to watch "Spaceballs 2" because Mel Brooks refers to it in the movie. Josh explained to her that there was actually no Spaceballs 2. That night, he dreamed the whole plot of Spaceballs 2, and then proceeded to call up Mel Brooks to pitch the movie. Whereby Mel said "Josh, I've been waiting 35 years for this phone call!". So they're making the movie. I don't even remember Spaceballs but I saw that clip on TikTok today (it was from an interview with Seth Meyer) and I thought it was funny so I had to share.

P.s. I didn‚Äôt even notice the anagrams which is good because I am bad at them.

"You're not dating Emily F. anymore?"
"No, she loved anagrams too much. I'd have to rearrange 'my life' for her."

("Yeah, I'd have mixed feelings about that.")

Fun fast puzzle, and yes a little simple for a Thursday.  The trick revealed itself quickly (in part because the revealer clue comes so early) and I have to agree with the constructor that the editors' version of linking the clue pairs is much better and more elegant than what he had.

I didn't like the clue for IOU at all, far too stretchy even though I got it fairly.  Other than that nit, a cute dialectical puzzle.  Minimal filler too.  Not every Thursday has to be a brain bender...
I have the feeling that @Andrzej will do really well with this puzzle. Mostly because he won‚Äôt need to figure out the anagrams, he‚Äôll just know the meanings of all the foreign words.

Overall I think it was a good puzzle, it took me a long time to figure out that the translated words were anagrams of the languages but when I realized from crossing clues that VALIANT was an anagram of LATVIAN the other two fell quickly.

I have a couple nitpicks, clues that hung me up at the end and when I figured it out I question them.  ANOINTS in particular I didn't think made sense as an answer to 'Designate'.  And since I have not heard of ANA De Armas and I didn't make the connection for TON that had me scratching my head even with most of the crossing clues.

im becoming increasingly fond of puzzlers who create layers within layers, mostly to amuse themselves, which are entirely unnecessary for solving the puzzle.
had the anagrammatic definitions based on the language names not been anagrams at all, the puzzle would have been just as zippy and clever.
as ive noted before, for me its an amuse-bouche reminiscent of the artists who included (and, i suppose, still include) obscure personal fillips in their canvases primarily for their own pleasure.
except here, in my dim-witted case, the morsel usually delights after the meal rather than before.

Loved this brilliant puzzle! I didn‚Äôt realize these were anagrams until I was done. And then we get a few more in the constructor notes! Love SHINGLE for English, I‚Äôll be thinking about this one for a while. Truly enjoyable. Thanks.

I didn‚Äôt catch on to the anagrams until the last one. I looked up at the others and kind of noticed a pattern even though they weren‚Äôt fully in, then the light bulb came on and I was able to fill in VA to complete VALIANT. Interestingly, I had all of the languages filled in based on a few letters in each of them. Then asked myself how in the world I would be able to figure out those translations and praying the crosses would take care of them, which of course they did. But that aha moment when I realized they all were anagrams was what made this one fun for me. I did somehow fat finger a C for a G in LOGOS and that took me way longer to find than it should have. Thanks, Sam. Looking forward to your next one.
Very enjoyable Thursday, and extra credit for the TIL that Swift introduced the name Vanessa

Anagrams? What anagrams? 

The Y in YOLO was the last to fall. 

It took a little longer having missed the point of the puzzle but it was still worth the effort. 

Thanks

I hate it when one of my favorite pastimes gets spoiled by poor choices people make. But enough about somebody skating to Coldplay at a recent ISU Grand Prix event. I'm rarely impressed by the construction of a puzzle, but this came close. Finding words the English translations of which were anagrams of the name of the original language - and then incorporating it all into a mostly enjoyable grid - can't have been easy. Well done. That being said, I was slightly put off by the themed non-English words being complete enigmas. Well, mostly, anyway. The Croatian "kabanica" sounds much like an old-fashioned Polish word for a coat - "kabat", which actually helped me solve one of today's anagrams. The etymology of the Polish word is not clear (there are at least two theories), but it being so similar to Croatian can't be pure coincidence, can it? For more language trivia: English has the word "turncoat". Well, in Polish the verb "przekabaciƒá" (literally, turn a coat) means to cause somebody to go turncoat. Kabaty also used to be a village that now is a sub-division of my Warsaw district of Ursyn√≥w. The village was probably named after its one-time owners, the Kabat family, who in turn somehow were named for a military coat. I solved the puzzle in Wednesday time but it did not feel easy, at all. I thought the difficulty was OK for this time in the week. And now for something completely different. Lucek the puppy sporting my wife's sweater: https://imgur.com/a/oXovIS3
Killer theme, got such a kick out of it. Also loved SHEESH and TOWZA, and TIL where the name VANESSA comes from, how fun. Easily my favorite clue in what was a very very straightforward puzzle.
Wow! Thanks Sam.

9:28 slower than my Thu average but now enjoying a 4 day streak. Quite liked this gimmick-free, use your noodle and keep at it puzzle. And happily none of my usual shake my head, what the's on a Thursday.

Enjoyed this, though, as others have said, it felt like a clever Wednesday rather than a Thursday. I daresay it‚Äôs much harder to construct than to solve, but a few more of the anagrams would have maybe lifted it.

My only real gripe is probably a British thing. I had spoof down for Spaceballs, and realised it wasn‚Äôt that quite quickly, but then kept inputting then removing FARCE because it didn‚Äôt feel like a good fit for Spaceballs. Maybe this is just the battle ground where theatre grads and film grads come to blows, but there‚Äôs more to Farce than just silly jokes; it‚Äôs a genre in which a whole conceptual escalation leads to ridicule, and Spaceballs is a ridiculous masterpiece but its core comes from, obviously, its distortion of its source material, and not from an original core concept.
This was WAY too easy. Of course, I‚Äôm fluent in Flemish, Croatian and Latvian.
Does anyone else ever scroll to the Tricky Clues section in search for help, only to find all the answers you thought were gimmes? I need an Easy Clue section it seems!

I caught on to the theme right away, which is not at all typical for me. Found it clever but much of the cluing seemed too straightforward for Thursday. As I filled in the top half, I kept having thoughts like, ‚Äò[Dressing choice] can‚Äôt really be as obvious as RANCH.‚Äô  

Speaking of languages, while traveling, my husband and I make a point to learn to say yes, no, hello, goodbye, please, thank you, bathroom, wine‚Ä¶the essentials, in the local language. Our Basque guide, Jon, taught us a few words in Basque (Euskara). We found it fascinating that Euskara has absolutely no relationship to any other language. According to Jon, no one knows why. My favorite word, and one that Jon insisted that we shout whenever we like something, is ekaragarria, which roughly translates to awesome.
Flemish is not an official language but a dialect of Dutch. Flemish is spoken in Flanders, the northern part of Belgium.

I found this to be very pleasant and not that tricky. I wasn't exactly sure what "Jeez Louise" meant, and fortunately got the solutions with the crossers, which I wasn't familiar with either. I only know RANCH from the crosswords, never tried it. I think olive oil and balsamic dressing is almost default over here. 


Anagrams are used a lot in British crosswords. Some involve working out which parts of the multi-part clue need to be used and which parts carry the meaning eg tar can mean a sailor (Jack Tar) as can AB (Able Seaman). 
For example - Able seaman Brown checked stuff in Scotland = Tartan.

If I found it quite easy, I expect this wasn't as challenging as many Thursdays. But no complaints.

This was fun.

Not as hard as most Thursdays, and it can be disappointing not to get a rebus, but the theme was clever. I filled in RAINbows before I realized I needed an anagram, which is also what told me that nIl was wrong for [zip].

Come clever cluing. I've heard of SHEA butter, but I wasn't sure of the spelling. (I also have no idea if SHEA is the obscure name of the plant it comes from, or something else.) An eponym, maybe?)

Not quite a PB, but well below average.

Thanks!

It's a good feeling when you pick up on a theme before you finish, which is rare for me, and helped me get the southwest corner quickly and finish at more than 7 minutes under my average Thursday. This theme might have made a fun Sunday grid... Especially if shingle/ English could have found its way in.
[Language in which ‚Äúrolulu‚Äù is PERSONATE]
Clever - and fun! Thank you Sam for a relatively painless Thursday puzzle. üòä
No surprise that NYT still doesn‚Äôt understand that ‚Äúokras‚Äù isn‚Äôt a thing people say.

The anagram twist sailed right over my head so was fun to learn that from Deb's column.  

"Kabanica" for RAINCOAT and "zichzelf" for HIMSELF were fairly easy guesses once a sufficient number of crosses were present but "drosmigs" for VALIANT - not so easy.  (I was stuck on VArIANT).  

Fun puzzle and many thanks.

Sam so far, in his three NYT puzzles has come up with themes where letters and words are re-arranged.  His last puzzle (7/1/25) featured parenthetical words within parenthetical words, and his first (6/1/25) was, like today‚Äôs, based on anagrams, where, i.e., CHANGE OF HEART was clued [EARTH].

I don‚Äôt know if re-arranging will be his wordplay niche, but I‚Äôm all for it!

The theme today is elegant, and high props to Sam for being the first to come up with it. The reveal has ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù-worthy wordplay punch.  Thus, one terrific theme.

My favorite serendipity in the grid today is the answer with a meta feel: MADE MAN, which simply anagrams to MAN MADE, which is what this puzzle is!

Smooth, fun, original, and elegant ‚Äì mwah!  Thank you, Sam!

Seemed very easy for a Thursday, and more a Wednesday puzzle thematically. 

EASTLA and BMOVIE were interesting entries. OKRAS in the plural was (still) grating.

Didn't find the theme all that exciting. Random language names along with anagrams. I suppose the revealer was at least apt.

Looking forward to something more challenging tomorrow.
Like a narrow valley. GLEN-ISH. Into the valley https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kGBRSuNK7Go
[Language in which ‚Äúlaitingplay‚Äù is PLAITING]
So much fun! Figured out the theme. Had to check one name. Breezed through it - surprisingly- for a Thursday. Just a joy to work through! Thanks, Sam! Y‚Äôall have a terrific Thursday!

Of all the....
The likes of....
Who in the...
What the...
How did....
Is this a....

In other words, SHEESH and YOWZA (you can't make me spell it  that way!) and congratulations.
I can hear the shrieks from here.
How did I even....
In what world...

Except for the fact that THERE IS NO SUCH THING AS "OKRAS"
this was the most amazing, baffling, clever, intriguing, FUN puzzle evah!  
More, please!

TIL that Jonathan Swift invented the name Vanessa.

According to the Internets, here's the story:
"The writer Jonathan Swift invented the name Vanessa as a pseudonym for his friend Esther Vanhomrigh. He created the name by combining the first part of her surname, "Van," with an affectionate diminutive of her first name, "Essa". The name first appeared in his 1726 poem, "Cadenus and Vanessa," which chronicled their relationship."
For those who like anagrams, there's a new game at the New Yorker that's anagram-adjacent: https://www.newyorker.com/puzzles-and-games-dept/shuffalo/2025/11/06

Enjoyed this one. But I agree about "okras." Come on, puzzle editors: kales? Arugulas?
Maybe if the clue were about variants (are there different kinds of okra?).

I mostly sped through this puzzle until a little hiccup in the SW had me going for a short while. I got the anagram theme at FLEMISH, which helped me get VALIANT, but couldn't understand why CROATIAN and Kabanica weren't anagrams. Until I did. Duh. I really need to stop doing these puzzles at 4 am when everyone east of here is still asleep and I'm not ready for that.

Had to smile at CROATIAN, evoking yet another memory of that first trip to Eastern Europe before the fall of communism. Those days there were no cell phones, no Apple or Google translate, and of course I didn't speak any of the languages. But I had what every traveler desperately needed: a Serbo-Croatian-English dictionary. We sat down to our very first meal in Croatia, lunch at an unassuming little outdoor restaurant. No matter wherever I traveled, I was determined to not get ripped off, so before we ordered, I translated every single item on the menu. I then ordered a "hamburger s kajmak sirom:, which came with a cheese of that particular region. When the bill came, there was an extra charge for the cheese. I was livid, and actually fought with the waiter, pointing to the menu, then to my dictionary, back and forth, until he had to choice but to remove the extra charge, which couldn't have been more than 15 cents. But it was the principle. I couldn't believe I'd fought and won with nothing more than a dictionary. Too bad that didn't work in Budapest, where we got ripped off much worse in an upscale restaurant.

I‚Äôve never looked this up before, but another poster‚Äôs musing prompted me to. Was SHEA Irish?

Nope. Shea comes from ‚Äòsi‚Äô, the word for ‚Äòshea tree‚Äô in Bambara, the most widely spoken of the official languages of Mali. Though Mali, like other parts of West Africa, was under French colonial rule until the 20th c., ‚Äòshea‚Äô comes to us via the travel literature of one Mungo Park, a Scottish explorer, who had managed to get to Mali before the French. The OED attests it first in his book titled ‚ÄòTravels in the interior of Africa, in the years 1795, 1796, & 1797:‚Äô

‚ÄúIn clearing wood land for cultivation, every tree is cut down but the Shea.‚Äù

What‚Äôs interesting is that English hadn‚Äôt pick up the already existing then French word for ‚Äòshea‚Äô‚Äî‚Äòkarit√©‚Äô‚Äîbefore Park went traipsing through what is Mali today. By the time Park got to Mali, the French had been sitting in West Africa for some time (though not in Mali), and in the process they had imported ‚Äòkarit√©‚Äô from Wolof, the language spoken today in Senegal, Gambia, and Mauritania. In Wolof shea is called ‚Äòkaarite,‚Äô which, acc. to Spanish Wikipedia, means ‚Äòpan de mono‚Äô or ‚Äòmonkey bread.‚Äô

(@Andrzej, this is for you: No relation between Fr. karit√© and Sp. carite (mackerel) or Med. Lat. karitƒÅs (charity) or Anc. Greek œáŒ¨œÅŒπœÑŒ±‚Äîkh√°rita (grace). Sometimes a false cognate is just a false cognate is monkey bread [smile]). 

Well, I suppose ‚Äòshea‚Äô does roll off the tongue more easily than [gargles in preparation] ‚Äòkarit√©.‚Äô
This is a Thursday puzzle?!
‚ÄúVim‚Äù is Zip???? Am I missing an acronym or something?

Thursdays have become to day when I auto-fill the themed answers. I just don‚Äôt have the energy or interest to figure these out, and today was no different. I do not find them fun or interesting aspects of my puzzle experience. Having long, drawn out answers that require a theme will probably never be my thing, and that‚Äôs okay. Today, the constructor decided to use lesser known words in languages I doubt most solvers will recognize simply for the obscurity and nothing more. It‚Äôs frustrating when this happens. I wish constructors didn‚Äôt feel the need to just Google the most obscure things they can and throw them in a puzzle and call it difficult. I find it lazy. Have a cookie. üç™

The rest of the puzzle is fine. Some ugly fill ‚Äî IOU, ANA, IVANA, NIA, BMW. Didn‚Äôt care for those at all. Trivia fests. 

YOWZAH and SHEESH are answers that couldn‚Äôt be deciphered on the clue‚Äôs own merits. Feel free to reach into the cookie jar for one more.

A lot of auto references which are my kryptonite just after sports teams/names. Still not sure I understand RAGES/LOGOS, which cost me the gold star as I wasn‚Äôt sure what was wrong or what I was looking at. I also don‚Äôt understand VIM at all.

Cool to learn that Swift invented the name Vanessa. Reminds me of J.M. Barrie inventing the name Wendy for his play Peter Pan.

I don‚Äôt know, a very ‚Äúmeh‚Äù puzzle for me, and I still dread Thursdays.

Have a great day!

VIM, vigor, elan all = zip.

Spaceballs has my favorite bumper sticker. See for yourself.

Thank you Sam and myself for remembering some of my Foreign Service Officers exam.

Fascinating puzzle, linguistically! Mr. Brody's accomplishment is impressive.

As a language nerd, I guess this was firmly in my wheelhouse; new PB for me, under 11 minutes. My Thursday average is nearly 22 minutes! I thoroughly enjoyed every second of the solve.
I still get embarrassed thinking about the time I dressed in a French maid's outfit when I thought I was interviewing to be a  maid man.
Clever clever!
Absolutely delightful puzzle!
Fantastic puzzle! Although, me thinks, we should retire the clue "Actress de Armas" for the foreseeable future.
Fantastic theme and well executed, I only wish he had used all the others he had found and made a nice big Sunday out of this!

How much wood could a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood? Where was I. Oh yeah - enjoyable puzzle and a typical Thursday workout. Thought it was really clever to make half of each of the pairs a different language. And this was one of those puzzles when catching on to the trick was a huge turning point. Side note: Moved over here to Austell a few years ago, but actually spent most of my time down here in Clarkston, GA which is often referred to as "The Ellis Island of the south," and "The most diverse square mile in America." Just had a lot of experiences of needing a translator to talk to some people. But that was all quite enjoyable. And finally - a puzzle find. A Friday from February 6, 1998 by Wayne Robert Williams. Don't recall another one quite like this. Theme answers: SHESELLSCSHELLS BYTHECSHORE CATTLECHAWK FROMCTOSHININGC Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/6/1998&g=17&d=A I'm done. ....

Brilliant! Loved the theme (twisting of the tongues) and the clueing (‚Äúmade man‚Äù was a fun one). Seeing the symmetry and looking at the letter patterns as they got filled in gave me hope that anagrams might be involved. I stumbled with guessing - Laotian and loo. Happy to have picked up a good conversation starter for my next Vanessa. 

41 minutes versus an average of 65.
Spent too long thinking CAUCUS wasn't a "real" word... "Cow-cuss, what the heck".
What a creative idea. Very impressive.
Hardly Thursday-esque.

We need TRICKIER Thursdays. Like we had before. TRICKS nobody ever seen before. New tricks, off the GRID invisible squares tricks. MAKE THURSDAY TRICK AGAIN

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

YOWZA!
I didn't figure out that there were anagrams until I got to VALIANT, when the V jumped up ans smacked me in the face.
SHEESH.
YOLO???

I liked it. Except Pot papers‚Ä¶. as a clue, it was a stretch. 

Fun and challenging theme.

What's a CAUCUh? And Smart COOKIt? Oh, right, it's SEIZE, and not hEIst üòÇ
For the first half, I was feeling a little underwhelmed and disappointed at the lack of a trick. Then I realized what was going on. Anagrams! I know they're not everyone's cup of tea, but I love them, and I just now realized what TONGUETWISTER means ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è very clever. I'm in awe of the thought that went into this one.
This was just great. I finished the puzzle, then went back to understand what exactly was the trick, and was delighted when I figured it out. Yes, it took two tries, but hey, it was still great fun.
Really enjoyed this one

Thanks for a very clever puzzle today, Sam, that surely took a tremendous amount of time to develop such a creative theme! Please keep them coming!

Shockingly -- as it's usually my most challenging day -- I got my best Thursday time today even with needing crosses to figure out the language translations. 

Happy Thursday, all!
Tricky, but doable and fun! This puzzle was so well designed! I loved all the echoing clues.
Wowzah!!!   Crazy good Thursday challenge, Sam!  Play it again anytime.

Loved this one. On first glance it seemed impossible, but I got through it with very few FLUBS and no lookups. Awesome theme. A couple nitpicks: I‚Äôve never heard OKRAS used as the plural form, so I avoided putting it in until it seemed obvious. And never heard of LAV, except as a lapel microphone.
This was a challenge to do without lookups. Some of the answers were informal usage, but not indicated, add to that some difficult crosses made for a very tough challenge in some areas.
What language does TEARS OPEN anagram to? It‚Äôs the only one I can‚Äôt figure out.
Okay no, this is one of those "Tell me how clever I am!" puzzles nobody else can solve. Yes yes, you're very clever, now give us a real puzzle.
While not a difficult solve, the clever theme still has me smiling. Ingenious! Anagrams and therefore tongue twisters. Wow!

So accustomed am I to Thursday rebuses that when I had _ _ GUE filled in for 31D, I was certain the answer was ‚ÄúMontague‚Äù. I definitely wasted some time trying to divide and squeeze the remaining letters appropriately.

Because of that, the reveal was a little bit ‚Äúoh, it‚Äôs just that?‚Äù for me, but I still found it enjoyable.
Fun puzzle. Not as challenging as Thursdays sometimes are, but every day without a rebus is a good day for me.

"To make this puzzle, I copied a long list of languages from Wikipedia, filtered them down and wrote a small program to look for anagrams."

That is just lazy.
Great fun - I love anagrams and wish the weekday puzzle offered room for more of them. Maybe for some future Sunday!

I did the puzzle, finally!

I had to rely upon my Croatian, Flemish and Latvian roots to solve the three-language ones. [NOT! ---just helpful crossings.]
Over five minutes scanning the puzzle for what square was wrong. BRASs instead of BRASH. SHEESH!
Flemish is as much a language as "American" would be. The language is Dutch.
Very fun one and a kick in the pants when I REALLY looked at the theme answers. Bravo!
Flemish? This was hard for those of us who only understand Walloonish.
What fun! .... and Sam Brody's list of unused anagrams was a lovely little extra
Language in which "aitingplay" is...

Ugh. I filled in the grid only to learn something was amiss. Found a misstep at 52A where I‚Äôd filled in sIP which didn‚Äôt fit with 50D. Corrected it, but still another error to locate?? Threw in the towel after much searching and was disappointed to learn my error was in RAcES and LOcOS. Still don‚Äôt know who that golden bull is. So close!
Well I had LOcO for LOGO and RAcES instead of RAGES but I liked the anagrams, Sam Brody!
Please never again this dude has absolutely impossible clues, sooo far from any relevance.  NOT. A. PLEASURE.

If you're still looking to be puzzled, today's Universal crossword "Swing States" has one of the best themes I've seen in a while. You can find links to that puzzle here: https://crosswordfiend.com/download/

Cool puzzle! I learned some new words (in different languages) and was impressed to find out- after the fact- that the English translations were anagrams for their language of origin. Wow! The rest of the puzzle felt like navigating several stumbling blocks for me, but this is the way it goes sometimes.
TONGUETWISTER was quite helpful to me, as I wouldn't have thought of anagrams without it. I was delighted to see CROATIAN in today's puzzle, as that is half my heritage.

@Andrzej I tracked down a translation for your medal and am shocked, shocked! to find that it involves your cultural icon, Chopin. I  guess the rhyme was just too hard to resist.
  So now I'm trying to invent a USA equivalent but I don't know that we US folks have a comparable cultural icon. I know the Russians used to call us something like "neculturny"; did Poles too?
  Also I couldn't find the etymology for the 1st word in the medal so still wondering how close it gets  to the translated BS. Off course US English has plenty of ways to say that!
  But it's been a fun rabbit hole to explore.

@D - it‚Äôs interesting to hear how differently we approach and enjoy Crosswords.  What you describe as enjoyable (or at least what I can interpret from learning what you dislike) is what I find to be meh and apparently vice versa.

Don‚Äôt get me wrong, I didn‚Äôt think today‚Äôs puzzle was a triumph, but I do enjoy sticky clues that are hard to parse and require working through the crosses and maybe some starts and stops and restarts to decipher.  

I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm simplifying, but it seems you like a puzzle where you can read a clue and just type in the answer.  If you have to take extra steps (e.g. examine the crosses), that is less enjoyable.  For me, that‚Äôs a Monday or Tuesday puzzle and those are fun only in that I try to go fast and break my record.

With late week puzzles, the reward is often the eureka moment when you figure out that RAINCOAT and CROATIA share the same letters and the remaining themed clues are not much more accessible.

In most cases, the answers are words you know and the clue is just trying to make it hard to recognize.  The clues that give me heart burn or names of authors or languages other than Spanish (Thanks NY State academic requirements!)

Anyway, happy to chat with my puzzle inverse and wish you nothing but puzzle satisfaction going forward.

@D

We are somewhat on the same page today, so I will pass on the cookie‚Äîalthough maybe for somewhat different reasons. Just wanted to clarify, the issue wasn‚Äôt that the translations were obscure or that anyone would be expected to know them, it was that they were anagrams of the language. I found that a little flat myself, and I know that would have been equally as unengaging for you given your lack of predilection for Thursdays‚Äîjust didn‚Äôt want you to leave with the impression that the constructor really expected anyone to know RAINCOAT in CROATIAN.

@SP Certainly not, but knowing the word was part of the clue. I appreciate your response but I do disagree, I think without the revealer, all that was left was  asking people to know the word. It‚Äôs part of why I don‚Äôt like revealer puzzles.

@D

Nah, I'm agreeing that in no way and on no planet were solvers asked or expected to know the cited translations.  It was a mild trick.

@D

I find it highly ironic that you call the constructor lazy, but you can‚Äôt be bothered to solve anything beyond a basic one-layer puzzle. 

I think, though, that because of your supposed preference, you‚Äôre missing out on a lot of fun. It could be that you‚Äôre just not ready for the higher-level puzzles yet, so it‚Äôs a shame you‚Äôve already decided you don‚Äôt like them. 

In the end, I don‚Äôt think NYT crosswords are a good match for you. Something more basic, like USA Today puzzles, might be more up your alley.
